attributes.title: Sharing Decisions Depending on the Source and Type of the Extra Resource

q1.value: Sharing Decisions of Children Depending on the Source and Type of the Extra Resource

q3.value: In this study, we plan to observe children’s prescriptive ideas on sharing in third party scenarios. Specifically, we ask whether children pay attention to why an agent has more resources than the other one (possible reasons: a- because this agent worked harder than the other one, b- their family had more resources, c- they got lucky) and think the agent who has more should share their resources with the other one differentially depending on the reason why they have more. We also ask whether the type of the resource (i.e. money vs bouncy balls) would affect children’s decisions.

q4.value: Overall, we expect to see a main effect of the resource type in the sense that children will think that the agent who got the extra resource should share more when this resource is bouncy balls than when it is money. We also expect to find an effect of the source of the extra resource. Specifically, we expect that children will think the largest amount of extra resource should be shared when this extra resource was acquired by luck, a lesser amount of resource should be shared when it was given to them because their family has more resources, and the least amount of resource should be shared when it was acquired because of merit. We also expect these main effects to be stronger for the older age group (8-9 ages) compared to the younger age group (5-6 ages).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a 3(setting of the scenario [playground, park, play center]) X 3 (the source of the extra resource [merit, inheritance, windfall]) X 2 (type of the resource [money vs. bouncy balls]) X 2 (age group [younger: 5-6 year-olds vs older: 8-9 year-olds]) mixed model design. The source of the extra resource is a within-subjects and the type of the resource is a between-subjects factor. The different settings' pairings with these two variables will be counterbalanced between and within subjects.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: For this study, 5, 6, 8, and 9 year-old children will be recruited from partnering schools, child-care programs or public museums in and around the city of New Haven. Additionally, families in Yale University’s Social Cognitive Development Lab database will be invited to visit the lab to participate in the study. Small thank-you gifts (e.g. key chains, small plush toys etc.) will be offered to the participants in exchange of their efforts.

q13.value: We are planning to collect data from 120 participants in total (N = 30 per cell for between subject variables that will be included to the main analysis [age group and resource type]).

question.value:
For each scenario we will ask these two questions:

a)	Do you think this child (pointing at the child who got more resource than the other one) should share some of their money/bouncy balls with the other child?
b)	(If the child says yes to question a) How much money/how many bouncy balls they should give to the other child?

First, we will use a mixed linear model predicting the number of resources that should be given as a function of:

The type of the resource, the source of the extra resource, age group of the participant, and all possible interactions of these three variables 

Analysis#1: lmer(give ~ resourType * resourSource * ageGroup + (1| subject))

Variables which have no main or interaction effects (as determined with a likelihood ratio test using the drop1 command) will be dropped from the model.

q22.value:
For each trial there are two control questions:
-	Could you show me the child who got 6(2) bouncy balls(dollars)?
-	Could you remind me whether these two children collected an equal number cans/ piled up an equal number of blocks/ planted an equal number of flowers (depending on the scenario) or did one of them … more?

Participants who fail to answer these questions will be corrected once, but they will be excluded from the analyses if they fail to answer correctly for a second time.

q24.value:
We are not expecting to find any gender effects, but we will test the data for it and add this variable into the main regression model if we find effects related to gender of the participants. 

We are not expecting to find setting effects either but we will also test the data for setting effects. If the settings are found to be behaving differently, we will test the suggested main regression model separately for different scenarios.

q1.value: Likert or Not: Effective Use of Likert Data in Visualization Evaluations

q3.value: Likert scales are often used to measure subjective response in visualization evaluation studies, but we find through a literature review that many researchers use inappropriate methods to collect, analyze, and report Likert scale data. We plan to conduct a simulation study to test the robustness of parametric and nonparametric methods when applied to scenarios encountered in visualization research. The results of our simulation study will inform a set of recommendations we are developing for best practices of Likert use in the visualization community.

q4.value:
H1: Nonparametric methods will be more robust (i.e. will see a lower increase in error rates) to non-Normality threats to validity than parametric methods. 
H2: Parametric methods will be more robust to the lack of independence threat to validity.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will simulate responses to a 7-point Likert scale collected through five different experimental designs: one sample, two sample (between subject), two sample (within subject), three sample (between subject), and three sample (within subject). For each experimental design, we will generate control datasets and violation datasets with two potential threats to validity: lack of independence and non-Normality. To simulate dependent datasets in the one sample case, we assume that a latent Normal variable exists between two groups within the sample. For two and three sample designs, we simulate dependence between treatment groups. We will calculate Type I and Type II error rates over 1000 iterations to compare the performance of tests. Datasets will be simulated with three sample sizes: 10, 30, and 100.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We generated several one sample datasets and ran initial comparisons between the sign test, Wilcoxon signed rank test, and Student T test. We did not generate or test any two- or three-sample datasets and the generation process changed significantly between pilot and final study. Four coauthors viewed the pilot data.

question.value:
The data will be generated randomly within each experimental design using Python. Samples of size 10, 30, and 100 will be simulated using five experimental designs (one sample, two sample (between subject), two sample (within subject), three sample (between subject), and three sample (within subject). Within each experimental design, a control group without any threats to validity will be generated for comparison with the other treatment groups. Parametric and nonparametric tests will be run on the same generated datasets. 
One sample design:
- Parametric: Student t test 
- Nonparametric: sign test and Wilcoxon signed rank test
Two sample (between subject) design:
- Parametric: Independent two sample Student t test
- Nonparametric: Mann-Whitney U test
Two sample (within subject) design:
- Parametric: Paired two sample Student t test
- Nonparametric: Wilcoxon signed rank test
Three sample (between subject) design:
- Parametric: ANOVA
- Nonparametric: Kruskal-Wallis test
Three sample (within subject) design:
- Parametric: Repeated Measures ANOVA
- Nonparametric: Friedman test

Each combination of sample size, experimental design, and threats to validity will be run 1000 times.

q13.value: 1000 iterations, each time generating samples with size 10, 30, and 100.

q14.value: We chose to generate samples of size 10, 30, and 100 because most of the Likert scale evaluations encountered in our survey of visualization literature had sample sizes in this range.

question.value: We will manipulate the sample size of generated datasets (n = 10, 30, and 100), the correlation between treatment groups (rho = 0, 0.3, 0.5, 0.8), the distribution that generated datasets are sampled from (Normal, Uniform, Beta, Logistic), the type of statistical methods used to test for significance in simulated datasets (parametric vs. nonparametric), and the size of the true difference present in the underlying populations that datasets are drawn from (one sample: 0-6, two sample: 0-6, three sample: 0-12).

For each iteration, we will collect the p-value returned by the given test for significance and record whether a Type I or Type II error was made based on the p-value and the characteristics of the population distribution that sample datasets were drawn from.
We will measure the Type I and Type II error rate for each combination of factors across 1000 iterations.
We are not using any statistical models to test our hypotheses.

q21.value: We will compare the error rates for assumption violation treatment groups with the error rates of the control group.

q22.value: We will not exclude any points or samples from our analysis.

q23.value: We are generating our dataset, so we won't have any missing or incomplete data.

attributes.title: The Role of the Parafovea and Eye Movements During Written Language Processing

q1.value: The role of parafoveal information and eye movements during written language processing

q3.value: Current literature suggests that, during reading, information is not only drawn from words falling within the centre of vision (the fovea), but also from items further towards the periphery (the parafovea). The extent to which this information is processed, and how it influences foveal word/sentence processing, has also received focus across psycholinguistic research; highlighting a general consensus around the capacity for the parafoveal extraction of phonological, orthographic, morphological and lexical information - though which more discrepancy surrounding semantic processing. Furthermore, there has been limited investigation into the role of eye-movements in this process since Rayner, McConkie, and Ehrlich (1978) first proposed that making an eye-movement is a prerequisite for parafoveal processing. On this basis, we will attempt to replicate Rayner et al.'s (1978) study while also manipulating the semantic relatedness of the previews following a study by Schotter (2013).

q4.value: We put forward a the hypothesis that semantically-related preview words, presented covertly in participants' parafoveal vision, will provide benefits to the processing of subsequently-presented target words compared to the processing of targets appearing after semantically-unrelated parafoveal previews. Specifically, we hypothesise that participants will show lower lexcial decision times and higher lexical decision accuracy when the preview words were semantically related to the target word than when they were unrelated. Compared to an identical control preview condition, the semantically related preview condition should show higher lexical decision times and lower lexical decision accuracy as the identical condition not only shares the semantical content, but also all other properties with the target word. We also hypothesise that this effect will only occur when participants have executed an eye-movement towards the preview word. Even though these hypotheses are directional, we will use standard two-tailed statistical tests as they are easier to implement.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A 2x3 within-subjects design and factorial within-subjects ANOVA will be used to compare reaction times (ms) of participants as they make lexical decisions about target words.  The target words are preceded by three different types of parafoveal preview words (semantically-related, semantically-unrelated or identical) and using two different tasks: in the first task condition, participants are instructed to make a saccade to the parafoveal word when it appears (at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen). Once participants cross an invisible boundary between the center of the screen and the parafoveal preview word, the parafoveal preview word is replaced by the target word. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (saccade condition). In the second task condition, participants are instructed to fixate on a fixation cross in the center of the screen during the entire trial. The preview word appears for 133 ms at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen. After 133 ms, the preview word disappears and the gaze target is replaced with the target word in the center of the screen. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (no-saccade condition). All the conditions will be counterbalanced such that, across participants, each item is seen in all the preview and task conditions. As the two tasks will be presented in blocks, we will also counterbalance which half of the items is seen first.

We will use a subset of the materials used by Schotter (2013). For the semantically related condition, we will use the synonyms from these materials. For the semantically unrelated condition, we will use the unrelated control words. We will exclude some of the target words and preview words that are uncommon in the UK or have specifically American spelling. For the nonwords, we used the English Lexicon Project (Balota et al., 2007) to determine the characteristics of Schotter's (2013) target words and generate a list of matched nonwords for a total of 106 word trials and 106 nonword trials. Additionally, we chose 20 practice words and 20 practice nonwords. During the practice trials, only identical previews will be presented. The stimulus lists are attached to this question. Note that half of the participants will see List 1 first and the other half will see List 2 first during the experiment.

The experiment was implemented in Opensesame. The experiment script is attached.

q9.value: The order in which the items are presented is randomized, however, the condition they are presented in is not (it is determined by the counterbalancing).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit as many native English-speaking participants as time permits until 11 May 2020, with a minimum of 12. Participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal vision and they do not have any condition that affects language processing. Participants will be recruited mostly, but not exclusively, from the Bournemouth University student population. They will be recruited using poster advertisements, the Bournemouth University Psychology online research participation system (SONA) and word-of-mouth. Those participants that require course credit will receive one SONA credit for their participation. Other participants will not be compensated for their participation.

q13.value: We will aim to recruit at least 12 participants. This is necessary for a full counterbalancing. If we recruit more than 12 participants, we will test in multiples of 12 to keep the data balanced.

q14.value: As this is an undergraduate dissertation study, the number of participants is limited by the available time until the project deadline.

q15.value: We will terminate data collection on 11 May 2020. Until then, we will recruit as many participants as possible (in multiples of 12) given time, participant and equipment availability.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of parafoveal preview shown to participants. The target words are preceded by three different types of parafoveal preview words (semantically-related, semantically-unrelated or identical) and using two different tasks: in the first task condition, participants are instructed to make a saccade to the parafoveal word when it appears (at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen). Once participants cross an invisible boundary between the center of the screen and the parafoveal preview word, the parafoveal preview word is replaced by the target word. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (saccade condition). In the second task condition, participants are instructed to fixate on a fixation cross in the center of the screen during the entire trial. The preview word appears for 133 ms at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen. After 133 ms, the preview word disappears and the gaze target is replaced with the target word in the center of the screen. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (no-saccade condition).

In order to measure the effect of different previews on participants' written-language processing, we will record the time it takes participants to make a lexical decision response to each target word. This time will be measured from the appearance of the target word on the screen to the participant's key press. We will also record whether each lexical decision response was correct or incorrect.
N/A

For the reaction times, a linear mixed model will be fitted with raw lexical decision times (in ms)  as the predicted variable and preview condition, task, and the interaction between preview condition and task as fixed effects. For the accuracy, we will use a generalized linear mixed model (gLMM) using a logit link with the same fixed effects. In both models, we will specify contrasts for the predictors as follows: for the preview condition, we will use two orthogonal contrasts: the first contrast will compare the identical condition (coded as -2) to the mean of the related and unrelated conditions (each coded as 1). The second contrast will compare the related condition (coded as -1) and the unrelated condition (coded as 1, with the identical condition coded as 0). For the task condition, we will use one contrast, with the saccade task coded as -1 and the no-saccade task coded as 1. For each model, we will use the maximum random effects structure that results in model convergence as recommended by Barr, Levy, Scheepers, and Tily (2013).

q20.value: In both models, we will specify contrasts for the predictors as follows: for the preview condition, we will use two orthogonal contrasts: the first contrast will compare the identical condition (coded as -2) to the mean of the related and unrelated conditions (each coded as 1). The second contrast will compare the related condition (coded as -1) and the unrelated condition (coded as 1, with the identical condition coded as 0). For the task condition, we will use one contrast, with the saccade task coded as -1 and the no-saccade task coded as 1.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the estimated coefficients are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. This will apply to all analyses.

q22.value: We will exclude reaction times lower than 300 ms and higher than 5000 ms. We will include all other outliers in the analysis.

q23.value: Trials with incomplete data will not be included in the analysis. Subjects and items with missing data will be included, as the (g)LMM is not strongly affected by missing data.

q24.value: We will perform Bayesian versions of the LMM and gLMM using the brms package in R.

A 2x3 within-subjects design and factorial within-subjects ANOVA will be used to compare reaction times (ms) of participants as they make lexical decisions about target words.  The target words are preceded by three different types of parafoveal preview words (semantically-related, semantically-unrelated or identical) and using two different tasks: in the first task condition, participants are instructed to make a saccade to the parafoveal word when it appears (at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen). Once participants cross an invisible boundary between the center of the screen and the parafoveal preview word, the parafoveal preview word is replaced by the target word. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (saccade condition). In the second task condition, participants are instructed to fixate on a fixation cross in the center of the screen during the entire trial. The preview word appears for 133 ms at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen. After 133 ms, the preview word disappears and the gaze target is replaced with the target word in the center of the screen. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (no-saccade condition). All the conditions will be counterbalanced such that, across participants, each item is seen in all the preview and task conditions. As the two tasks will be presented in blocks, we will also counterbalance which half of the items is seen first.

We will use a subset of the materials used by Schotter (2013). For the semantically related condition, we will use the synonyms from these materials. For the semantically unrelated condition, we will use the unrelated control words. We will exclude some of the target words and preview words that are uncommon in the UK or have specifically American spelling. For the nonwords, we used the English Lexicon Project (Balota et al., 2007) to determine the characteristics of Schotter's (2013) target words and generate a list of matched nonwords for a total of 106 word trials and 106 nonword trials. Additionally, we chose 20 practice words and 20 practice nonwords. During the practice trials, only identical previews will be presented. The stimulus lists are attached to this question. Note that half of the participants will see List 1 first and the other half will see List 2 first during the experiment.

The experiment was implemented in Opensesame. The experiment script is attached.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit as many native English-speaking participants as time permits until 11 May 2020, with a minimum of 12. Participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal vision and they do not have any condition that affects language processing. Participants will be recruited mostly, but not exclusively, from the Bournemouth University student population. They will be recruited using poster advertisements, the Bournemouth University Psychology online research participation system (SONA) and word-of-mouth. Those participants that require course credit will receive one SONA credit for their participation. Other participants will not be compensated for their participation.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the type of parafoveal preview shown to participants. The target words are preceded by three different types of parafoveal preview words (semantically-related, semantically-unrelated or identical) and using two different tasks: in the first task condition, participants are instructed to make a saccade to the parafoveal word when it appears (at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen). Once participants cross an invisible boundary between the center of the screen and the parafoveal preview word, the parafoveal preview word is replaced by the target word. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (saccade condition). In the second task condition, participants are instructed to fixate on a fixation cross in the center of the screen during the entire trial. The preview word appears for 133 ms at 1.21 degrees of visual angle to the right of the center of the screen. After 133 ms, the preview word disappears and the gaze target is replaced with the target word in the center of the screen. Participants then perform the lexical decision task (no-saccade condition).
registration_responses.q17.question: In order to measure the effect of different previews on participants' written-language processing, we will record the time it takes participants to make a lexical decision response to each target word. This time will be measured from the appearance of the target word on the screen to the participant's key press. We will also record whether each lexical decision response was correct or incorrect.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question: For the reaction times, a linear mixed model will be fitted with raw lexical decision times (in ms)  as the predicted variable and preview condition, task, and the interaction between preview condition and task as fixed effects. For the accuracy, we will use a generalized linear mixed model (gLMM) using a logit link with the same fixed effects. In both models, we will specify contrasts for the predictors as follows: for the preview condition, we will use two orthogonal contrasts: the first contrast will compare the identical condition (coded as -2) to the mean of the related and unrelated conditions (each coded as 1). The second contrast will compare the related condition (coded as -1) and the unrelated condition (coded as 1, with the identical condition coded as 0). For the task condition, we will use one contrast, with the saccade task coded as -1 and the no-saccade task coded as 1. For each model, we will use the maximum random effects structure that results in model convergence as recommended by Barr, Levy, Scheepers, and Tily (2013).

attributes.title: An Experimental Study of the Social Context of Political Information

q1.value: An Experimental Study of the Social Context of Political Information

q5.value: The financial support from Florida State University is gratefully acknowledged.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: At the heart of representative democracy lies what some scholars have referred to as ``the democratic dilemma,'' which is when ordinary citizens lack the political expertise to make good decisions. As a consequence of this, and declines in political engagement more broadly, scholars have suggested that, in order to better reach the democratic ideal of an informed and engaged electorate, policies that improve voters' overall knowledge of politics should be given greater priority. It is argued in the literature that enriching community ties, with policies that encourage cultural, spiritual, and neighborhood activities, will increase overall engagement in politics, thus improving the quality of democratic choice. But if this logic holds, it stands to reason that such changes will lead to a different dilemma that arises from strategic incentives - the dilemma of free-ridership. Specifically, if an individual, in addition to gaining expertise on political issues, also learns that there are many other similarly minded expert voters, will she necessarily have an increased incentive to participate? We will conduct experiments that address the quality of democratic choice made by individual voters who have the same goals to study how the social context of political information affects the quality of democratic choice and voters' willingness to participate in elections. Using a novel experimental design we will directly elicit voters' willingness to vote which allows us to examine several distinct collective action issues that arise in democratic decision-making.

q16.value: There are generally two ways that the social context administering political knowledge among voters might manifest (on average): 1, Solidarity: knowing that one is not alone, an expert voter might be driven by a sense of solidarity with other expert voters. In this case, revealing the number of voters with expertise increases an individual expert voter's propensity to vote; 2, Instrumentality: being told how many expert voters are present at election time may sharpen an individual voter's incentive to free ride. In this case, revealing how many voters have expertise may sharpen an individual expert voter's incentive to free-ride. The quantities of interest are the elicited intension to vote, willingness to vote, and based on the elicited information, we will calculate the quality of democratic choice, which is the probability that the majority preferred alternative is collectively chosen by voters. We will detail how we will measure these quantities in the attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: The experiment will be conducted at Florida State University where subjects will be registered university students. The experiment will be programmed using z-Tree (Fischbacher2007) and conducted via computerized network. Subjects will be seated at individual computer terminals and not allowed to see other subjects' choices. Our main experimental manipulation will alter what voters know about each other by altering the manner in which political expertise is administered. In particular, in the Treatment Group, voters will be told how many of them have political expertise, whereas in the Control Group this information will remain hidden. We will focus on expert voters' participation in democratic decision-making First, if voters are primarily motivated by a psychological desire to join others in the social act of voting, then informing voters of the number of expert voters, by activating a sense of solidarity, should increase an expert voter's desire to participate. Consequently, giving such a voter the concrete knowledge that there are other expert voters should increase her propensity to vote, which translates into an increase in the quality of democratic choice. Alternatively, a voter may be motivated by more self-centered considerations, such as the probability her vote will be pivotal, and will react very differently to being informed of the number of other expert voters. In this case, administering this kind of knowledge about other voters can decrease an expert voter's willingness to vote, thus decreasing the quality of democratic choice. Our experiment will adjudicate between these two alternative ways voters might respond to aspects of their social environment by assessing which influence---solidarity or instrumentality---dominate on average.

q19.value: We will recruit 120 subjects. 60 for the Control Group and 60 for the Treatment Group

attributes.title: National and International Experiences on Knowledge Translation to  improve Maternal, Neonatal and Perinatal Care at Technical, Professional, and Traditional Level: Systematic Review of Literature and Meta-analysis: Protocol

q1.value: Experiencias Nacionales e Internacionales sobre Transferencia de Conocimiento para el Mejoramiento de la Atención Materna, Neonatal y Perinatal a Nivel Técnico, Profesional, y Tradicional: Protocolo Revisión Sistemática de la Literatura y Metanálisis

q2.value: Juan J. Yepes-Nuñez, Sandra Milena Montoya Sanabria, Yesika Tatiana Hernández Sandoval, Diana Catalina Díaz Barrero, Sergio Augusto Cáceres Maldonado, Dauris Lineth Mejía Pérez, Yuldor Eduardo Caballero Díaz

q3.value:
Se ha reconocido que las inequidades estructurales y los recursos limitados han agregado barreras a la utilización de la evidencia en el área salud pública. A pesar de la variedad de intervenciones costo-efectivas que promueven la salud materna, perinatal y neonatal, estas no se aplican. En este aspecto recae la necesidad de establecer las razones que dificultan la transferencia del conocimiento o la efectividad de las estrategias que garanticen este propósito, en tanto se reconoce que la mayor parte de la carga de muerte prematura y enfermedad entre los más vulnerables se debe a problemas para los que se reconocen soluciones y es posible la prevención. 
En este contexto, la transferencia del conocimiento se considera un proceso transversal y no lineal que involucra no solo hallazgos de investigaciones recientes, sino el conocimiento creado a partir de la interacción dinámica de personas que buscan resolver problemas de salud pública, aprender y, en última instancia, impulsar un cambio productivo.
De esta manera, el objetivo de este proyecto es resumir sistemáticamente las experiencias nacionales e internacionales sobre transferencia de conocimiento, específicamente que se concentren en el periodo de intercambio de conocimiento, para el mejoramiento de la atención materna, neonatal y perinatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional.

q4.value: ¿Cuáles son las experiencias y/o estrategias de transferencia de conocimiento, nacionales e internacionales para la atención en salud materna, neonatal y perinatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Revisión Sistemática de Literatura (RSL) y Metanálisis (MA) para identificar las experiencias nacionales e internacionales de intercambio y/o transferencia de conocimientos entre profesionales, técnicos y tradicionales en la atención materno, perinatal y neonatal.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
*Criterios de inclusión: se incluirán estudios que hayan descrito o evaluado intervenciones/estrategias para transferencia/intercambio de conocimiento, transferencia/intercambio interprofesional (incluyendo partería profesional), intercomunitaria, profesional-comunitaria y/o profesional/técnica-comunitaria en salud materna y neonatal.

* Estudios cuantitativos, aleatorizados y no aleatorizados que documenten experiencias de intercambio de conocimiento y saberes entre personal profesional, técnico y/o tradicional durante intervenciones que busquen mejorar salud materno-perinatal y neonatal desarrollados en población gestante, perinatal y en neonatal (hasta el día 28 de vida). 

*Estudios cualitativos que describan/ documenten experiencias de intercambio de conocimiento y saberes por parte de personal profesional, técnico y/o tradicional para mejorar la salud materno-perinatal y neonatal 

* Se revisarán igualmente estudios secundarios de síntesis de evidencia desarrollados en población gestante y en neonatos (hasta el día 28 de vida), en donde se describan las estrategias(formas) de intercambio de saberes y/o conocimientos entre el personal profesional, técnico y/o tradicional con el fin de obtener estudios primarios que puedan ser de interés para esta RSL.

** Bases de datos electrónicas: se desarrollará una estrategia de búsqueda para identificar la mayor cantidad de estudios relevantes y disponibles. Se combinarán los términos claves libres, y términos MeSH, EMTREE y DeCS, a través de las siguientes bases de datos vía Ovid: Medline, CINAHL, Embase, PsycInfo, Lilacs, Wholis, Web of Science, ERIC, PASCASL IPA y/o Jstor. Se buscarán las referencias sin límite de tiempo ni restricción en el lenguaje. En el Anexo 1 se presenta la estrategia de búsqueda para Medline (vía Ovid)

** Otros recursos: adicionalmente, se accederá a la literatura gris nacional e internacional, definida esta como cualquier tipo de documento que no se difunde por los canales ordinarios de publicación comercial (18). La búsqueda se realizará a través de diferentes portales informativos de tipo gubernamental y no gubernamental: Ministerios de Salud de América Latina, Ministerios de Salud de África, Secretarías de Salud, Organizaciones No-Gubernamentales (ONGs), Agencias de Naciones Unidas, OpenGrey, WONDER, PAHO IRIS y documentos emitidos por grupos y/o asociaciones de partería profesional. Por otra parte, se explorarán los repositorios bibliográficos de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, la Universidad de los Andes y la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana en búsqueda de otros documentos que puedan contener información relevante.

question.value:
* Selección de estudios: dos revisores seleccionarán de forma independiente los artículos que cumplan con los criterios de inclusión, mediante la revisión de los títulos y los resúmenes. Luego de obtener los textos completos de los artículos seleccionados, dos revisores de forma independiente revisarán los artículos completos aplicando nuevamente los criterios de inclusión. Este proceso permitirá seleccionar los artículos finales que serán incluidos en la RSL.

* Extracción de datos: dos revisores de forma independiente revisarán artículos que fueron seleccionados mediante el proceso de cribado y resumirán la información de forma tabular en una hoja de extracción de datos. Los dos evaluadores discutirán los desacuerdos que se presenten durante este proceso y, de ser necesario, llegarán a un acuerdo mediante la consulta con un tercer revisor.

Los revisores extraerán la siguiente información de los artículos seleccionados: tipo de estudio, metodología, características de los participantes, intervención, tiempo y método de medición de desenlaces, la duración del estudio y el patrocinador del estudio. Después de completar de forma independiente la extracción de los datos, los revisores llevarán a cabo un proceso iterativo para llegar a la lista de las experiencias nacionales e internacionales sobre transferencia de conocimiento para el mejoramiento de la atención materno - neonatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional.

Los procesos de cribado sobre el texto completo de los artículos y la extracción de datos serán estandarizados con el fin de minimizar potenciales pérdidas de información. Para tal fin, se llevará a cabo una calibración inicial de los revisores mediante la aplicación de los criterios de inclusión y exclusión, sobre una muestra de artículos que hayan sido seleccionados previamente por el asesor metodológico. Este proceso permitirá definir el nivel de concordancia entre los revisores. La concordancia corregida por el azar para la evaluación de elegibilidad de los artículos en el proceso de texto completo y la extracción de datos se abordará utilizando el índice Kappa (concordancia corregida del azar). Los criterios de inclusión se revisarán y aclararán según sea necesario para garantizar una alta concordancia entre los revisores (un nivel de concordancia mayor al 70% o una estadístico kappa mayor que 0.6). Los revisores resolverán cualquier desacuerdo a través de discusiones y, de ser necesario, consultarán a un tercer revisor.
N/A

1. Desenlaces Maternos

* Morbilidad materna extrema: definida como cualquier complicación que pone en riesgo la vida de la mujer, pero sobrevive. Incluye el periodo gestacional, parto y los primeros 42 días post parto. Debe cumplir al menos uno de los siguientes criterios:

- Relacionado con enfermedad específica:

* Eclampsia
* Pre-eclampsia severa
* Sepsis o infección sistémica severa 
* Hemorragia obstétrica severa
* Ruptura uterina.

- Relacionado con disfunción orgánica:

* Falla vascular
* Falla renal
* Falla hepática
* Falla metabólica
* Falla cerebral
* Falla respiratoria 
* Falla de coagulación

- Relacionado con manejo:

* Necesidad de transfusión
* Necesidad de UCI
* Necesidad de procedimiento quirúrgico de emergencia

* Mortalidad materna: definida como aquella muerte de una mujer mientras está embarazada hasta un año después la terminación del embarazo.

* Alteraciones de la salud mental materna: definido por cualquiera de las siguientes morbilidades mentales maternas, como depresión pre y post natal, trastorno obsesivo compulsivo, trastorno de estrés postraumático y psicosis posparto.

2. Desenlaces durante el parto

* Vía del parto: definido como parto por cesárea, parto vaginal espontáneo, parto vaginal asistido (fórceps/vacío) o instrumentado.

* Desgarro perineal que requiere sutura: definido como cualquier desgarro que se produce en las partes blandas del canal del parto, afectando al periné (rafe medio y musculatura del periné, así como vagina) que requiere sutura.

* Satisfacción de la mujer en su atención de parto: definido como la satisfacción percibida por las mujeres gestantes con la experiencia del parto y el nacimiento de un hijo y que está relacionada con las expectativas personales de las mujeres, el alivio del dolor, el apoyo recibido tanto por los familiares como por los profesionales de la salud, la calidad de la relación con estos últimos, así como el cumplimiento de las expectativas de las madres. Esta satisfacción puede ser medida a través de cuestionarios específicos o genéricos.

3. Desenlaces posparto

* Promoción de la lactancia materna: definido como cualquier programa, estructurado o no, de apoyo a la lactancia materna en etapas pre y postnatal que recomiende la lactancia materna exclusiva hasta los 6 meses y fomente la prolongación de esta hasta los 2 años, acompañada a una adecuada alimentación complementaria.

* Desenlaces neonatales

- Mortalidad perinatal: definida como la muerte que ocurre en el periodo comprendido entre las 22 semanas completas (154 días) de gestación o con 500 gramos o más de peso fetal, hasta los siete días después del nacimiento

- Mortalidad neonatal: definida como la muerte ocurrida entre el nacimiento y los primeros 28 días completos de vida e incluye:

- Muertes neonatales tempranas: ocurren durante los primeros 7 días de vida (0-6 días).

- Muertes neonatales tardías: ocurren después de los 7 días completos hasta antes del día 28 de vida (7-27 días).

- Morbilidad neonatal compuesta: definido cualquiera de las siguientes morbilidades tales como por un puntaje de Apgar de cinco minutos menor o igual a siete, admisión del neonato a unidades de cuidados intensivos, morbilidad respiratoria que incluyen membranahialina, taquipnea transitoria, neumotórax, síndromes aspirativos, ventilación mecánica, CPAP; y otras morbilidades que incluyen ictericia/fototerapia, hipoglucemia, nutrición parenteral, sepsis precoz, convulsiones y encefalopatía hipóxico-isquémica.
N/A

* Síntesis de datos: se llevará a cabo un metanálisis utilizando un modelo de efectos aleatorios y utilizando el método de varianza inversa. Presentaremos las forest plot para cada desenlace de donde podamos extraer los datos.

q23.value: 8.2.	Datos perdidos: el análisis principal será llevado a cabo sobre los de datos disponibles en cada uno de los artículos. Si un artículo presenta datos por intención de tratar y por protocolo, usaremos el primero.

q24.value:
* Análisis de subgrupos e investigación de la heterogeneidad: realizaremos análisis de subgrupos para determinar si existe una respuesta distinta entre la atención materno -neonatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional de acuerdo con las siguientes características:

** Morbilidad materna extrema que incluye aquella relacionada con una enfermedad específica, disfunción orgánica o con el manejo de la atención del parto.

** Tipos de enfermedades de salud mental materna que incluyen depresión pre y post natal, trastorno obsesivo compulsivo, trastorno de estrés postraumático y psicosis posparto.

** Vía del parto que incluyen parto por cesárea, parto vaginal espontaneo, parto vaginal asistido (fórceps/vacío) o instrumentado.

** Mortalidad neonatal temprana o tardía

** Morbilidad neonatal que incluye puntaje de Apgar de cinco minutos menor o igual a siete, admisión del neonato a unidades de cuidados intensivos, morbilidad respiratoria (membrana hialina, taquipnea transitoria, neumotórax, síndromes aspirativos, ventilación mecánica, CPAP), y otras morbilidades (ictericia/fototerapia, hipoglucemia, nutrición parenteral, sepsis precoz, convulsiones y encefalopatía hipóxico-isquémica).

** Análisis de sensibilidad: llevaremos a cabo un análisis de sensibilidad para determinar el efecto de los siguientes parámetros en las estimaciones del efecto del tratamiento: 1) riesgo de sesgo: incluyendo solo estudios de bajo riesgo de sesgo; 2) modelo de metanálisis: aplicación de un modelo de efectos fijos en comparación con un modelo de efectos aleatorios.

q25.value:
* Evaluación de la heterogeneidad: evaluaremos la heterogeneidad clínica examinando los estudios aleatorios y no aleatorios, las características de los participantes, las intervenciones, los controles y la definición de los desenlaces. Se evaluará la heterogeneidad estadística a través del estadístico I2. Utilizaremos un punto de corte de I2> 50% para indicar una heterogeneidad estadística relevante. Se determinarán las causas de la heterogeneidad a través de análisis de sensibilidad y análisis de subgrupos.

* Evaluación del sesgo de publicación: exploraremos el sesgo de publicación mediante el gráfico en embudo (25) solo en el caso de tener diez o más estudios disponibles (26).

registration_responses.q1: Experiencias Nacionales e Internacionales sobre Transferencia de Conocimiento para el Mejoramiento de la Atención Materna, Neonatal y Perinatal a Nivel Técnico, Profesional, y Tradicional: Protocolo Revisión Sistemática de la Literatura y Metanálisis
registration_responses.q2: Juan J. Yepes-Nuñez, Sandra Milena Montoya Sanabria, Yesika Tatiana Hernández Sandoval, Diana Catalina Díaz Barrero, Sergio Augusto Cáceres Maldonado, Dauris Lineth Mejía Pérez, Yuldor Eduardo Caballero Díaz
registration_responses.q3:
Se ha reconocido que las inequidades estructurales y los recursos limitados han agregado barreras a la utilización de la evidencia en el área salud pública. A pesar de la variedad de intervenciones costo-efectivas que promueven la salud materna, perinatal y neonatal, estas no se aplican. En este aspecto recae la necesidad de establecer las razones que dificultan la transferencia del conocimiento o la efectividad de las estrategias que garanticen este propósito, en tanto se reconoce que la mayor parte de la carga de muerte prematura y enfermedad entre los más vulnerables se debe a problemas para los que se reconocen soluciones y es posible la prevención. 
En este contexto, la transferencia del conocimiento se considera un proceso transversal y no lineal que involucra no solo hallazgos de investigaciones recientes, sino el conocimiento creado a partir de la interacción dinámica de personas que buscan resolver problemas de salud pública, aprender y, en última instancia, impulsar un cambio productivo.
De esta manera, el objetivo de este proyecto es resumir sistemáticamente las experiencias nacionales e internacionales sobre transferencia de conocimiento, específicamente que se concentren en el periodo de intercambio de conocimiento, para el mejoramiento de la atención materna, neonatal y perinatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional.
registration_responses.q4: ¿Cuáles son las experiencias y/o estrategias de transferencia de conocimiento, nacionales e internacionales para la atención en salud materna, neonatal y perinatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional?
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11:
*Criterios de inclusión: se incluirán estudios que hayan descrito o evaluado intervenciones/estrategias para transferencia/intercambio de conocimiento, transferencia/intercambio interprofesional (incluyendo partería profesional), intercomunitaria, profesional-comunitaria y/o profesional/técnica-comunitaria en salud materna y neonatal.

* Estudios cuantitativos, aleatorizados y no aleatorizados que documenten experiencias de intercambio de conocimiento y saberes entre personal profesional, técnico y/o tradicional durante intervenciones que busquen mejorar salud materno-perinatal y neonatal desarrollados en población gestante, perinatal y en neonatal (hasta el día 28 de vida). 

*Estudios cualitativos que describan/ documenten experiencias de intercambio de conocimiento y saberes por parte de personal profesional, técnico y/o tradicional para mejorar la salud materno-perinatal y neonatal 

* Se revisarán igualmente estudios secundarios de síntesis de evidencia desarrollados en población gestante y en neonatos (hasta el día 28 de vida), en donde se describan las estrategias(formas) de intercambio de saberes y/o conocimientos entre el personal profesional, técnico y/o tradicional con el fin de obtener estudios primarios que puedan ser de interés para esta RSL.

** Bases de datos electrónicas: se desarrollará una estrategia de búsqueda para identificar la mayor cantidad de estudios relevantes y disponibles. Se combinarán los términos claves libres, y términos MeSH, EMTREE y DeCS, a través de las siguientes bases de datos vía Ovid: Medline, CINAHL, Embase, PsycInfo, Lilacs, Wholis, Web of Science, ERIC, PASCASL IPA y/o Jstor. Se buscarán las referencias sin límite de tiempo ni restricción en el lenguaje. En el Anexo 1 se presenta la estrategia de búsqueda para Medline (vía Ovid)

** Otros recursos: adicionalmente, se accederá a la literatura gris nacional e internacional, definida esta como cualquier tipo de documento que no se difunde por los canales ordinarios de publicación comercial (18). La búsqueda se realizará a través de diferentes portales informativos de tipo gubernamental y no gubernamental: Ministerios de Salud de América Latina, Ministerios de Salud de África, Secretarías de Salud, Organizaciones No-Gubernamentales (ONGs), Agencias de Naciones Unidas, OpenGrey, WONDER, PAHO IRIS y documentos emitidos por grupos y/o asociaciones de partería profesional. Por otra parte, se explorarán los repositorios bibliográficos de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, la Universidad de los Andes y la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana en búsqueda de otros documentos que puedan contener información relevante.

registration_responses.q8.question: Revisión Sistemática de Literatura (RSL) y Metanálisis (MA) para identificar las experiencias nacionales e internacionales de intercambio y/o transferencia de conocimientos entre profesionales, técnicos y tradicionales en la atención materno, perinatal y neonatal.
registration_responses.q12.question:
* Selección de estudios: dos revisores seleccionarán de forma independiente los artículos que cumplan con los criterios de inclusión, mediante la revisión de los títulos y los resúmenes. Luego de obtener los textos completos de los artículos seleccionados, dos revisores de forma independiente revisarán los artículos completos aplicando nuevamente los criterios de inclusión. Este proceso permitirá seleccionar los artículos finales que serán incluidos en la RSL.

* Extracción de datos: dos revisores de forma independiente revisarán artículos que fueron seleccionados mediante el proceso de cribado y resumirán la información de forma tabular en una hoja de extracción de datos. Los dos evaluadores discutirán los desacuerdos que se presenten durante este proceso y, de ser necesario, llegarán a un acuerdo mediante la consulta con un tercer revisor.

Los revisores extraerán la siguiente información de los artículos seleccionados: tipo de estudio, metodología, características de los participantes, intervención, tiempo y método de medición de desenlaces, la duración del estudio y el patrocinador del estudio. Después de completar de forma independiente la extracción de los datos, los revisores llevarán a cabo un proceso iterativo para llegar a la lista de las experiencias nacionales e internacionales sobre transferencia de conocimiento para el mejoramiento de la atención materno - neonatal entre los niveles profesional, técnico y tradicional.

Los procesos de cribado sobre el texto completo de los artículos y la extracción de datos serán estandarizados con el fin de minimizar potenciales pérdidas de información. Para tal fin, se llevará a cabo una calibración inicial de los revisores mediante la aplicación de los criterios de inclusión y exclusión, sobre una muestra de artículos que hayan sido seleccionados previamente por el asesor metodológico. Este proceso permitirá definir el nivel de concordancia entre los revisores. La concordancia corregida por el azar para la evaluación de elegibilidad de los artículos en el proceso de texto completo y la extracción de datos se abordará utilizando el índice Kappa (concordancia corregida del azar). Los criterios de inclusión se revisarán y aclararán según sea necesario para garantizar una alta concordancia entre los revisores (un nivel de concordancia mayor al 70% o una estadístico kappa mayor que 0.6). Los revisores resolverán cualquier desacuerdo a través de discusiones y, de ser necesario, consultarán a un tercer revisor.

registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Desenlaces Maternos

* Morbilidad materna extrema: definida como cualquier complicación que pone en riesgo la vida de la mujer, pero sobrevive. Incluye el periodo gestacional, parto y los primeros 42 días post parto. Debe cumplir al menos uno de los siguientes criterios:

- Relacionado con enfermedad específica:

* Eclampsia
* Pre-eclampsia severa
* Sepsis o infección sistémica severa 
* Hemorragia obstétrica severa
* Ruptura uterina.

- Relacionado con disfunción orgánica:

* Falla vascular
* Falla renal
* Falla hepática
* Falla metabólica
* Falla cerebral
* Falla respiratoria 
* Falla de coagulación

- Relacionado con manejo:

* Necesidad de transfusión
* Necesidad de UCI
* Necesidad de procedimiento quirúrgico de emergencia

* Mortalidad materna: definida como aquella muerte de una mujer mientras está embarazada hasta un año después la terminación del embarazo.

* Alteraciones de la salud mental materna: definido por cualquiera de las siguientes morbilidades mentales maternas, como depresión pre y post natal, trastorno obsesivo compulsivo, trastorno de estrés postraumático y psicosis posparto.

2. Desenlaces durante el parto

* Vía del parto: definido como parto por cesárea, parto vaginal espontáneo, parto vaginal asistido (fórceps/vacío) o instrumentado.

* Desgarro perineal que requiere sutura: definido como cualquier desgarro que se produce en las partes blandas del canal del parto, afectando al periné (rafe medio y musculatura del periné, así como vagina) que requiere sutura.

* Satisfacción de la mujer en su atención de parto: definido como la satisfacción percibida por las mujeres gestantes con la experiencia del parto y el nacimiento de un hijo y que está relacionada con las expectativas personales de las mujeres, el alivio del dolor, el apoyo recibido tanto por los familiares como por los profesionales de la salud, la calidad de la relación con estos últimos, así como el cumplimiento de las expectativas de las madres. Esta satisfacción puede ser medida a través de cuestionarios específicos o genéricos.

3. Desenlaces posparto

* Promoción de la lactancia materna: definido como cualquier programa, estructurado o no, de apoyo a la lactancia materna en etapas pre y postnatal que recomiende la lactancia materna exclusiva hasta los 6 meses y fomente la prolongación de esta hasta los 2 años, acompañada a una adecuada alimentación complementaria.

* Desenlaces neonatales

- Mortalidad perinatal: definida como la muerte que ocurre en el periodo comprendido entre las 22 semanas completas (154 días) de gestación o con 500 gramos o más de peso fetal, hasta los siete días después del nacimiento

- Mortalidad neonatal: definida como la muerte ocurrida entre el nacimiento y los primeros 28 días completos de vida e incluye:

- Muertes neonatales tempranas: ocurren durante los primeros 7 días de vida (0-6 días).

- Muertes neonatales tardías: ocurren después de los 7 días completos hasta antes del día 28 de vida (7-27 días).

- Morbilidad neonatal compuesta: definido cualquiera de las siguientes morbilidades tales como por un puntaje de Apgar de cinco minutos menor o igual a siete, admisión del neonato a unidades de cuidados intensivos, morbilidad respiratoria que incluyen membranahialina, taquipnea transitoria, neumotórax, síndromes aspirativos, ventilación mecánica, CPAP; y otras morbilidades que incluyen ictericia/fototerapia, hipoglucemia, nutrición parenteral, sepsis precoz, convulsiones y encefalopatía hipóxico-isquémica.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements at local pastry shops. Participants will be paid $10 for agreeing to participate (raised to $30 if our sample size is not reached within 15 days of beginning recruitment). Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to eat the ingredients of the pastries.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 280 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 320, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

question.value: We manipulated the percentage of sugar by mass added to brownies. The four levels of this categorical variable are: 15%, 20%, 25%, or 40% cane sugar by mass.

The single outcome variable will be the perceived tastiness of the single brownie each participant will eat. We will measure this by asking participants ‘How much did you enjoy eating the brownie’ (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being ‘not at all’, 7 being ‘a great deal’) and ‘How good did the brownie taste’ (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being ‘very bad’, 7 being ‘very good’).

We will use a  2 X 3 repeated measures ANOVA (RMANOVA) with both factors within subjects to analyze our results.  This is perhaps the most important and most complicated question within the preregistration. Ask yourself: is enough detail provided to run the same analysis again with the information provided by the user? Be aware for instances where the statistical models appear specific, but actually leave openings for the precise test.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will verify that each subject answered each of the three tastiness indices. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the three indices of tastiness, that subject will not be included in the analysis.
